title: Georgia House - Day 39 (2026-04-02)
summary:
Here is a summary of the key points from the Georgia House session transcript:

**Overview**:
The session featured a prayer and remarks by Rabbi Hershey Minkowitz, who discussed the significance of Passover and its timing in the spring. The session also included the daily opening procedures like roll call and the Pledge of Allegiance.

**Key Actions**:
No substantive legislation was passed or referred during this session. The focus was on the religious observance and opening formalities.

**Bills Introduced (First Reading)**:
No new bills were introduced.

**Notable Moments**:
- Rabbi Minkowitz gave a 2-minute explanation of why Passover is celebrated in the spring according to the lunar calendar.
- His prayer reflected on the themes of renewal, liberation, and hope that come with the spring season and Passover observance.

**Votes**:
No recorded votes took place.

**Attendance**:
The speaker noted that all members were present and should come to the floor to signify their attendance.

**Adjournment**:
The session did not adjourn, as it was the start of the day's proceedings.

Our chaplain this morning will be introduced by the gentleman from the 48th House District, Representative Scott Hilton. Chairman Hilton. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Your committee on information, sorry, I've got the wrong. That's the wrong thing. Hold on. Good morning, colleagues. God is good. Amen. The Hebrew word for peace is Shalom, and with two days remaining in the legislative session, there is no better person to bring us some Shalom than Rabbi Hershey Minkowitz. I'll say he shared with me in his house they have 11 children. So I'm guessing he has very little Shalom in his house, but he's going to bring some to this house today. In the summer of 1998, Rabbi Hershey Minkowitz was sent to Alfreda by the Chabad movement. Lady from the 51st, I'm getting a thumbs up. Thank you. A subsection of the Orthodox Jews to establish a Jewish worship and educational center for a growing Jewish community in North Fulton. Rabbi Hershey, as he's affectionately known, leads the Chabad of North Fulton until this day. Their center has become a primary address where Jews of all walks of life and religious backgrounds gather for Jewish enrichment and inspiration. Colleagues, please join me in welcoming Rabbi Hershey. Thank you. Good morning. A friend of mine recently told me that he took one of those private space tours to go see the moon. And when he came back, he told me, would you believe it? They even have a restaurant out there. I asked him, how was the food? He said the food was delicious, but the atmosphere was terrible. I hope you won't mind if I'm going to give you a brief two-minute spiel about the moon. I'm not an astronomer. There was not in the bio that Representative Hilton just read. It's just that next weekend we're going to be celebrating Passover. On April 12th, the Jewish community is going to be celebrating Passover. Interestingly, last year in 2024, Passover began on April 24th, 12 days later than this year. And in 2023, Passover began on April 5th. So why does it fluctuate? Let me quickly tell you the last five years since 2020 and see if you can detect the pattern. 2020, Passover started on April 8th, March 27th, 22nd, April 15th, 23rd, April 5th, 24th, and this year, April 12th. Every year Passover gets 11 or 12 days earlier than the year before, and then every two or three years, it gets set back a month ahead. Why is that? Well, in the book of Exodus, chapter 12, just before the Jews were leaving Egypt, God told the Israelites that from that point forward, they would begin keeping their calendar based on the cycle of the moon. Every month when a new moon appears, it's a new moon appears, it's a new month. Passover is always going to be on the 15th day of the first month when the moon is the fullest. And then in Exodus, chapter 13, verse 4, as the Jews are leaving the shackles of bondage behind, God says to them, and I quote, today you are going out in the month of spring. Rather than focusing on the name of the month, God is focused on the season, the fact that we're going out in the spring. So much so that later in Deuteronomy, just before the Israelites are about to enter into the promised land, God gives them a very firm reminder about how important it is to keep the holiday of Passover in the month of spring. Deuteronomy 161, you shall keep the month of spring and make the Passover offering to the Lord your God for in the month of spring, the Lord your God brought you out of Egypt. Sounds easy enough. However, to just one small problem, and that's why the holiday date varies every single year. You see the lunar calendar, the calendar that goes according to the cycle of the moon has 354 days, 11 days less than a solar calendar of 365 days. So every year Passover is going to get 11 days earlier and 11 days earlier. But hold on a second, God told the Jewish people that they have to keep the Passover in the spring. How is that possible if every year it gets 11 days earlier? So after a few months, Passover will end up being in the winter and then in the fall and then in the summer until it came back around again to the spring. Therefore, the Jewish calendar has a very complicated system where every few years we add a leap year, but not a leap year like in the regular calendar where it's one extra day, we add a full month. We end up with a year that has 13 months in a leap year instead of 12. All for this one reason, because Passover always has to be in the spring. So the million dollar question, and that will be the entry point into our prayer today, is why? Why did God care so much that Passover should always fall in the spring? To the point that we tinker with our calendar, to make sure that it stays in the spring, that the holiday of liberation should be always in the month of spring. Well, I'd like to ask you all to rise for prayer now as we pray and reflect on this idea of the spring. Mr. Speaker and the esteemed members of the Georgia State House, our Father in Heaven is teaching us something extremely important about freedom and liberty, the foundations upon which our great republic was founded. What does the spring represent? Honourable Speaker and esteemed members of the House. As we gather today in this chamber, I offer a reflection rooted in the spirit of renewal and hope that comes with the season of spring and the observance of Passover. Passover, a time of remembrance and freedom, invites us to reflect on the journey of the Israelites from bondage to liberation. It is a season that marks not only the liberation of people, but also the renewal of life itself. Just as the plants awaken from their winter rest in the spring, blossoming into vibrant new growth, so too can we embrace the opportunity to renew our commitments to justice, peace, and the well-being of our people. Spring reminds us that from the coldest and darkest of times, life finds a way to bloom again. It is a time to sow seeds of kindness, compassion, and progress for the future. Just as the earth comes alive with new growth, let us also plant the seeds of positive changes in our hearts and in our work, nurturing them with wisdom and care. So let us pray that we in our roles as leaders and servants of the people, draw inspiration from the season of renewal, embracing the promise of new beginnings and the hope that each day offers. Let this time of Passover remind us of our shared humanity, our capacity for transformation, and our duty to lift up those in need. May our work in this house be guided by the spirit of liberation, renewal, and growth, and may it be a fruit for the prosperity and peace for all Georgians, amen. And now please join me in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance. I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America and to the Republic for which it stands, one nation under God, indivisible with liberty and justice for all. Thank you.
